This is all things considered from NPR News I'm Michelle Martin we are broadcasting from Pittsburgh today at member station W E s say
We're here because yesterday eleven people were killed after a gunman entered the tree of life synagogue in a historic squirrel hill neighborhood of Pittsburgh today the city and indeed the country and many around the world are in mourning and trying to make sense of what happened here
Threw out this program we will be sharing what we know about the attack and we will be hearing from members of the community who were directly affected by the tragedy and
We'll hear from people who were far away but still felt the need to respond but we're going to start the program with Pittsburgh Mayor Bill but you know Mr Mann thank you so much for talking with us
It's my pleasure and of course I Want to offer my deepest condolences to you and to members of the city and the community and you've just last eleven people and how are you holding up and how is the city holding up
Um it's difficult uh our hearts are broken collectively in Pittsburgh is a community is small a Pittsburgh is a small city and what happens to one part of it affects all of us
We'd ask the number of people to describe this community to us and I'm like you to describe it to us what is what a squirrel hill all about
Well it's um I live five blocks from where are the event took place um it's the most diverse neighborhood and all of western Pennsylvania and it's I'm a very tight knit community that is the historic
A base of Pittsburgh's Jewish community for over one hundred years
Unfortunately um events like this are no longer rare in American Life and I wondered when you have seen other communities face something like that
You have seen other communities face something like this
Has it been running through your mind like what would I Do in the situation I mean as you first got the call this the first calls were coming into this with this event is taking place I find myself wondering like what were you thinking and how'd you how'd you thought to yourself who I think that you would have to face something like that
So I have a um strategy with my chief of staff on weekends or if he calls I I'm may not pick up on the first time but if he ever calls back
Two times all know that it is something that is a crisis it was the first time he's ever had to do that
And during that period I realized that something was very very wrong
Of within five minutes he was at my house and
We were on the scene I'm within five minutes of that so I'm looking at different cities of course there's always tried to learn from other cities and uh one of the examples and I
Had the opportunity to talk to them era Walsh today was Boston in the Boston Marathon and I'm trying to realize how to get not only the strategy of the police in public safety but also communications
And you know obviously this is early days and you're still dealing with the immediate aftermath and there are many there were going to be some really difficult
